title: Circular motion - to slow or not to slow

content.question: Two cars, Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are going around the same horizontal curve. Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> maintains a constant speed throughout the turn, while Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> slows down at a constant rate. At the moment when both cars have the same speed, which car experiences a greater magnitude of acceleration and why?

choices.label: Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The acceleration of Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is zero because it moves with constant speed.
Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The car’s acceleration is the vector sum of both tangential and centripetal accelerations.

Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The centripetal acceleration of Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is less than that Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>’s because Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is slowing down.

Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The centripetal acceleration of Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is partially canceled by its tangential deceleration.

content.answer: Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The car’s acceleration is the vector sum of both tangential and centripetal accelerations.
